questions.text: A medicine resident was having strain of his calf muscle during his emergency day. He kept working despite pain and his Head said it to be due to stress induced analgesia. The probable chemical responsible for this would be____
questions.solution:
Cannabinoids are endogenous chemicals, which act by CB1 and CB2 receptor to induce euphoria and analgesia. It helps to induce analgesia in stressful conditions like a battle. A soldier feels no pain until the battle is over due to these cannabinoids.

Incorrect Option A:Endrophins induces supra spinal analgesia

Incorrect Option B: Autacoids are local hormones that rather induce algesia.

Incorrect Option D: Glucocorticoids are released in stress but produces no significant analgesia.

Topic: Neurotransmitter

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 8, page number 173

questions.text: Orderly organization of Ca++ channels nearby Active zone of presynaptic membrane in a synapse requires____
questions.solution:
For effective synaptic functioning Ca++ channels of presynaptic membrane must be close to the receptors of postsynaptic membrane and active zone of release site. Such orderly arrangement is under influence of Neurexin. like a battle.

Incorrect Option A: Synaptobrevin is v-snare protein for vesicular traffic in the interior.

Incorrect Option C: Netrin and Semaphorins are tropic factor to guide nerve growth.

Incorrect Option D: Syntaxin is t-snare protein for vesicular traffic in the interior.

Topic: Neuromuscular junction

Very Important Question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 6, page number 121

questions.text: The ratio of total number of cells in human body and total number of synapses in nervous system, Ratio is?
questions.solution:
There are 100 Trillion cells in human body. There are 0.1 trillion neurons and each neuron makes on an average 2000 synapse. So total number of synapses will be 200 Trillion. So ratio of Cells: Synapse = 100 Trillion: 200 Trillion-> 1: 2

choices.text: Increased motor neuron discharge in agonist muscles results in rigidity
Decreased motor neuron discharge in agonist muscles results in rigidity

Decreased motor neuron discharge in agonist and antagonist muscles results in rigidity

questions.text: A male of 76 years is presented with resting tremor, cogwheel rigidity and bradykinesia. He walks with a stooped posture. The patient is being administered with L-dopa. How is rigidity different from spasticity
questions.solution:
Rigidity is different from spasticity because motor neuron discharge increases to both the agonist and antagonist muscles.

An increase in motor neuron discharge to only agonist muscles results in spasticity

Decrease in motor neuron discharge causes hypotonia

questions.text: Alpha sub unit of TSH receptor is identical to Alpha subunit of_________

very imp question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 19, page number 345

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, during Rinne's test, could hear the vibrations when the tuning fork was placed on the mastoid process but as soon as the fork was brought near the ear in air, she could not hear the vibrations. She most likely has:
questions.solution:
Normally, air conduction (AC) is more than bone conduction (BC) so the patient continues to hear the vibrations after the fork is bought in air from the mastoid process. Since the patient could not hear it in air, the hearing is impaired.

The patient suffers from conducive deafness as the bone conduction is normal but abnormality of the conduction pathway interferes with AC.

In case of partial nerve deafness, vibration is heard in the air after bone conduction is over.

In case of total nerve deafness, the patient does not hear the sound at all.


Topic: Hearing test

Light reflex present accommodation reflex absent
Light reflex absent accommodation reflex present
Light reflex and accommodation both absent

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with syphilis. The patient shows Argyll Robertson pupil. What would be the most likely finding in such a patient during examination of pupillary reflexes
questions.solution:
This is a case of Argyll Robertson pupil. Since the fibers carrying the light reflex can be damaged due to damage of pretectal-superior colliculi region and syphilis is the most common cause, light reflex is lost. The fibers carrying accommodation reflex takes a different route and are not damaged thus accommodation reflex is preserved.


Topic: Light reflex

Clinical

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 189

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is presented with generalized edema. The urine analysis shows the presence of protein. The patient was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following is the cause of edema in nephrotic syndrome
questions.solution:
Due to loss of proteins through urine, their concentration in plasma decreases, this results in decreased plasma oncotic pressure, which allows fluids to enter interstitial space, and causes edema.

Increased interstitial hydrostatic pressure, Decreased interstitial oncotic pressure and Decreased plasma hydrostatic pressure would cause fluid movement into the vessels and wouldn't cause edema

Topic: Fluid homeostasis

Contralateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of lesion and ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion

Ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of lesion and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion

Contralateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of lesion and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion

questions.text: A patient comes into emergency department after a fall. On examination, the patient was found to have a functional hemisection of the spinal cord. What would the patient be most likely experiencing
questions.solution:
Hemisection of the spinal cord damages the ascending tracts and descending tracts. This is called Brown-sequard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of lesion. The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Topic: Hemisection of spinal cord

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 177

questions.text: Which one of the following diseases is a son most likely to inherit from his father when his mother neither is a carrier nor affected by the disease?
questions.solution:
Acute intermittent porphyria shows autosomal dominant inheritance, characterized by a deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS). Occurs in heterozygotes for an HMBS pathogenic variant that causes reduced activity of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase.

Acute intermittent porphyria results from mutations in the HMBS gene, which causes about 50% of HMBS deficiency. The gene is on the 11q24.1-q24.2 chromosome. This deficiency is noticeable in the acute attacks, where the heme pool in the liver gets used, and there is the induction of delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS1). This process leads to delta-aminolevulinic (ALA) accumulation and porphobilinogen (PBG), which are the immediate precursors proximal to the HMBS.

Topic: Genetics

Clinical question

Reference:

  1. Guyton and Hall. Textbook of Medical Physiology. 14th edition. Page number 446.
  2. Peter Ronner. Netter's Essential Biochemistry, Page number. 152.

questions.text: Which type of conduction is shown in the image
questions.solution:
The conduction that takes place in myelinated neurons is saltatory conduction as the myelin sheet is an effective insulator and no sodium channels are present where the current can be exchanged. The current can only be exchanged at node of Ranvier where sodium channels are present and hence the polarization in myelinated axons jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next.

Conduction of impulses from the Synaptic junctions or receptors along axons to their termination is called orthodromic Conduction and conduction in the opposite direction is called antidromic conduction.

A current occurring in the normal or forward direction of conduction that is away from the cell body is called as anterograde conduction.

Topic: Nerve fibers

Important question

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 88

Image source: Guyton and Hall textbook of medical physiology, 14th edition

questions.text: A 6-month-old has had recurrent bouts of pneumonia, and a chest X-ray shows a greatly reduced thymus. Gene therapy would successfully treat this disorder if the gene is placed in which cell type or organ?
questions.solution:
The child has adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency, or SCID (severe combined Immunodeficiency disease). The circulating blood cells pick up deoxyadenosine, which is toxic in the absence of adenosine deaminase, a necessary enzyme for the metabolism of deoxyadenosine. By incorporating functional ADA in bone marrow cells, the stem cells for the production of the circulating blood cells now express ADA, and the mature cells produced from the stem cells will now express ADA, and be resistant to the toxic effects of deoxyadenosine.

Topic: Cell physiology

Clinical question

Reference:

  1. Guyton and Hall .Textbook of Medical Physiology.14th edition. Page number 46.
  2. Michael A. Lieberman. Lippincott's illustrated Q and A review of biochemistry. First Edition. Page number -55.

choices.text: Pyridostigmine can be administered in this case
Thymectomy is indicated especially if a thymoma is suspected
It is caused by the formation of circulating antibodies to the muscle type of muscarinic cholinergic receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was suffering from weakness and fatigability since 1 month. Patient is complaining of a decreasing ability to read that is more pronounced in the evening. The difficulty is due to a combination of diplopia and blurred vision. The probable diagnosis is Myasthenia gravis. The following statements are true except :
questions.solution:
Myasthenia gravis is a serious and sometimes fatal disease in which skeletal muscles are weak and tire easily. It is caused by the formation of circulating antibodies to the muscle type of acetylcholine receptor (nicotinic cholinergic receptors).

There are two major forms of the disease. In one form, the extraocular muscles are primarily affected. In the second form, there is a generalized skeletal muscle weakness. In severe cases, all muscles, including the diaphragm, can become weak and respiratory failure and death can ensue.

Topic: Muscle physiology

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page number. 132

questions.text: In which condition there will be spontaneous attacks of flail-like, intense and violent movements affecting whole of the opposite half of body ?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus is a rare disease caused by damage of subthalamic nucleus leads to sudden flailing movements of an entire limb, a condition called Hemiballismus.

Chorea is characterized by rapid, jerky, involuntary movements (dancing like movements). It occurs due to damage to caudate nucleus. Chorea is seen frequently in children as a complication of rheumatic fever.

Athetosis is characterized by slow, rhythmic, twisting, worm-like, confluent writhing movements of the extremities, affecting chiefly the fingers and the wrists. It occurs due to damage to putamen. Athetosis may occur in children following birth injuries.

Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is caused by copper toxicity resulting from impaired biliary excretion of dietary copper. Toxic effects are most pronounced in the liver and brain.

Topic: Abnormal movement

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page number. 721

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following membrane transport is affected in this patient ?
questions.solution:
In this patient suffering from hypercholesterolemia, there will be defect in the process of receptor mediated endocytosis.

Receptor-mediated endocytosis takes place in coated pits or indentations where the cytoplasmic side of the membrane has high concentrations of protein. The most common protein found in coated pits is clathrin. A GTP binding protein dynamin is involved in pinching off the vesicle formed in clathrin-mediated endocytosis.

Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is responsible for the internalization of many receptors and the ligands bound to them-including, for example, nerve growth factor (NGF) and low-density lipoproteins. It also plays a major role in synaptic function.

Topic: Membrane transporter

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page number 46

questions.text:
From the Below Given Statement comment whether they are true or false?
1. Gain in homoeostatic mechanism is mainly applicable For Negative feedback mechanism.(T/F)
2. All the Positive feedback mechanism are part of Largely Negative feedback process.(T/F)
3. All the Positive feedback mechanisms do not end with Negative feedback process.(T/F)
4. Feed forward mechanism do not have time lag present and mainly seen in nervous system.(T/F)
5. Most efficient feedback mechanism in human body is Baroreceptor mechanism.(T/F)
6. Homoeostasis means maintenance of constancy in the internal environment of the body; this definition is given by Walter. F. Cannon and the term homoeostasis was coined by Claude Bernard.(T/F)
questions.solution:
1. Gain is the measure of efficacy of mainly the negative homoeostatic mechanism; it is not so applicable to the positive feedback mechanism GAIN=CORRECTION/ERROR. Correct Statement.
  2. As positive feedback mechanism is a Vicious Cycle which mainly maximises the error it is ended largely Via The Negative Feedback For Example oxytocin in parturition and platelet plug and clot formation after the beneficial effect they are stopped by negative homoeostatic mechanism. Correct Statement.
  3. As explained in option number two, positive feedback mechanisms all end with negative feedback mechanisms because they are largely a part of the scheme of negative homoeostatic mechanisms. This Statement is incorrect.
  4. Feedforward mechanism is mainly defined as the system anticipates the change and makes the change before the action occurs which is defined as Feedforward Mechanism of Homoeostasis no time lag is present because the change occurs before the action and mainly seen in the Central nervous system. Correct Statement.
  5. The most efficient system or mechanism in the human body is Body fluid regulation in the renal system for blood pressure because it has a minimum amount of error so the gain in homoeostatic mechanism becomes maximum. Incorrect statement.
  6. Homoeostasis term was given by Walter.F.Cannon and internal environment of the body definition was given by Claude Bernard also called Milieu Interior. Incorrect Statement.

Topic: Homeostasis

Imp question

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition Page number -7, 8, 9, 10

choices.text: Tetrodotoxin, Salmon Fish, Calcium Channel Blocker
Tetra Ethyl Ammonium, Mamba snake venom, Potassium channel Blocker
Tetrodotoxin, Puffer Fish, Sodium Channel Blocker

questions.text: An Adult Male Residing nearby the Coastal Region Presented to the Physician with the Symptoms of Hypotension, Respiratory Depression, Decreased Sensation, Bradycardia On his History Taking He Mentions That He is a Non-Vegetarian Fond of Eating Sea Food and Recently Consumed Lots of Fish during His Meal. He was diagnosed with Sea Food Poisoning and Treatment Steps Were Proceeded. What could be the Toxin Responsible, Possible Fish Name, Mechanism of this Resulting Condition?
questions.solution:
Pufferfish contains a highly toxic substance, which is called as Tetrodotoxin, which blocks the Sodium Channel Present on the membrane, which results in disruption of Impulse conduction, which results in the mentioned symptoms in the given question it occurs due to the lot of Consumption of the Pufferfish.

Another example of Sodium channel blocker is Saxitoxin.

In Option A calcium channel blocker example is Verapamil which does not correlate with the mentioned scenario of the question and the fish mentioned is not related.

In Option B the mentioned toxin is presented during a mamba snake poisoning case scenario in which the toxin is tetra ethyl ammonium which blocks the potassium channel.

Topic: Membrane channel

Clinical question

Reference: Guyton and Hall 2nd south Asia edition, page number : 67, 68

questions.text:
A researcher is studying the physiology of skeletal muscle contraction. Arrange the following in the ascending order of occurrence of signal transmission at the neuromuscular junction:
A. Neurotransmitter degradation
B. Exocytosis
C. Calcium influx
D. End Plate potential
questions.solution:
The neuromuscular junction (NMJ) is responsible for the chemical passage of an electrical impulse from a neuron to a muscle (skeletal/ smooth/ cardiac) to create an adequate muscle contraction.

The following is the order of signal transmission at the neuromuscular junction:

Calcium influx - Exocytosis-End Plate potential - Neurotransmitter degradation - Calcium influx produces-cholinergic exocytosis, which results in end plate potential. Acetylcholi nesterases then break down the acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, thus stopping the transmission.

Topic: Transmission of impulse across N-M junction

Clinical question

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th edition, page number 93-100

questions.text: A 23-year athletes Lifting a weight of 2 kg from the ground. In this activity which type of phenomenon will be observed, answer from following;
questions.solution:
During lifting of weight, isotonic type of muscle contraction is observed.

Two types of muscle contraction are there one isotonic and second is isometric, in Isotonic muscle contraction there will be the change in length so work done is take place. Work done not take place in isometric contraction as the length of muscle not changed.

Clonus - muscle remain in the state of contraction

Fatigue - reversible phenomenon in which muscle contraction is not possible further for the particular time, site of the fatigue in isolated tissue preparation is NM junction while site of fatigue in human being is central synapse

Topic: Muscle contraction

Clinical question

Reference: G K pal textbook of physiology 2nd edition. Pagenumber. 215-276

questions.text: Malignant hyperthermia is a rare condition of very high increase in body temperature that usually occurs on exposure to anesthetics or depolarizing neuromuscular blockers. Malignant hyperthermia is treated with?
questions.solution:
The plasma calcium concentration rises abnormally that severely activates myosin ATPase activity. The consequent hyperactivity and hypermetabolic processes rapidly increase core temperature.

Treatment is by immediate use of dantrolene sodium that decreases the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Topic: NM blockers
